summary.p: [1] Bullinger thanks for the letter written in the field camp near Nördlingen on October 8 [Letter No. 2616]. Since then, he has endeavored to act as best as possible in the spirit of the Landgrave, whose goal is to defend Christianity and the freedom of Germany against the attack of Emperor [Charles V].

[2] Through the letter of the four [Protestant] places, the Landgrave will learn what these places decided at their meeting in Zürich. Yesterday [Saturday, October 30], the Zürich council gathered the councils and the citizens, who clearly stood [behind him]. Next Sunday [assemblies will be held] in the counties and lordships [of the Zürich region]. [One hopes for] all the best from this.
[3] The Landgrave thus sees the good will [of the Zürich council], which is doing its utmost.
[4] He is thanked for sending Bullinger another [war] report [with his letter of October 8], as he did on September 12 with letter HBBW XVII, No. 2581.

div.p: I have received your princely grace's gracious letter, dated in the field camp near Nördlingen, October 8, and have understood its contents. I have applied my utmost diligence to promote everything possible here that serves the good of your princely grace's intentions, namely to preserve the Christian religion and the German nation against the attack of the Emperor.

Your princely grace will have understood through the letter of the four cities, along with their associates, what they decided at their meeting here. Since then, my gracious lords, the council and citizens have united to inform all the communities in the city. This happened yesterday, and a unanimous response was given. Next Sunday, assemblies will be held in the counties and lordships, where one hopes for all the best.
Your princely grace thus sees that I have nothing but good will and favor, and that I do everything possible at all times.
I express my great thanks for your princely grace informing me once again.
I willingly offer my services, wherever I can.
